892664CB3878458AAE4C4E4913B66788.description:
trace the development of a technological application that has altered an ecosystem (e.g., power
generation, fishing, logging, oil and gas exploration, agricultural practices)

B9CBBF9C40494330B6E9E7B06C6174CD.description:
describe the relationship between land use practices and altering ecosystems (e.g., swamp
drainage, slash and burn forestry, agriculture)

94F0E7D24C5A4A4CAF24FD199DE920AA.description:
assess the impact of the introduction of exotic species on a specific ecosystem or biome (e.g.,
purple loosestrife in western Canadian wetlands, English sparrows in North America, zebra
mussels in the Great Lakes)

26996C9CF33B49A49442BCDB0778C7C2.description:
describe how interactions among organisms limit populations (e.g., predation, parasitism,
competition)

DE7CDC483ECD4E2D857B9B30E1E5BFE6.description:
explain how various factors influence the size of populations; i.e., immigration and emigration,
birth and death rates, food supply, predation, disease, reproductive rate, number of offspring
produced, and climate change

C78A9272F15C480A9E949FB7AD79EF4E.description:
explain how biotic relationships can be explained in terms of the movement of matter and energy,
using food chains, food webs and energy pyramids

834120530B7C4C9BBD2FD0325A9FA22C.description:
describe how various abiotic factors influence biodiversity in an ecosystem (e.g., climate,
substrate, temperature, elevation)

64E642008F72497EB73CF8187DDAF57D.description:
define ecosystems in terms of biotic and abiotic factors (e.g., common plants and animals,
latitude, altitude, topography)

4C4FA193ACE74F20920B813E4C4DAADC.description:
describe, in general terms, the characteristics of two Alberta biomes (e.g., parkland, boreal forest,
mountain, grassland)

6AC0BEC7B4024D258A69B540346968CB.description:
Analyze a local ecosystem in terms of its biotic and abiotic components, and describe factors of the
equilibrium

ADF3618FF77D4436BE6FED4BEF11816C.description:
identify and assess the needs and interests of society that have led to technologies with
unforeseen environmental consequences (e.g., fishing technologies that result in harvesting more
than the rate of reproduction, use of pesticides such as DDT, impact of driving a car on
atmospheric compositions)

B722651F72504F4EBAE34625B1D10FA7.description: assess the impact of modern agricultural technology on the natural pathways of recycling matter

BD8D9FB68EB04EF19E6B2C22D510CE91.description: compare the recycling of matter by society with the natural cycling of matter through ecosystems

7FCC459437A447C0955E080289151E76.description: explain why the flow of energy through the biosphere is linear and noncyclical

CA8A1FF9B83A4D31BE666E26421B8201.description:
describe, in general terms, how water, carbon, oxygen and nitrogen are cycled through the
biosphere

EA9F1AC424474BF09E280E01DB6D29B9.description:
explain how biodegradable materials reduce the impact of human-made products on the
environment

5A5959EEE3AD4D30A486015DFEB2C00A.description:
assess the costs and benefits of technological developments that produce materials the ecosystem
cannot recycle (e.g., disposable plastics, heavy metals)

82B0DA32CF3B4D2CA9475E94CE6EE1F8.description: explain the role of living systems in the cycling of matter in the biosphere (e.g., food chains)

FA67E30E5F2B44E3A2465D9D0FDF54AC.description:
Describe how the flow of matter in the biosphere is cyclical along characteristic pathways and can be
disrupted by human activity

C54CBB2CD2A8466D891C0DBCD121D5E0.description: Investigating Matter and Energy in the Environment

556C6A01775F4D7FBC06ADC987790D4E.description:
identify and describe the role of modern technology in monitoring critical life functions in
humans (e.g., ultrasound, heart monitor, blood pressure cuff, blood glucose monitoring devices)

93F0F99002AC4F0AB7434B4A804F81EA.description:
describe how cell structure has been adapted for specific life functions (e.g., stomata in the leaves
for water balance; skin cells are flat to cover large surface area; plant cell walls provide
structural support; nerve cells are long for transmission of impulses; storage of chemical energy
in roots [e.g., sugar beets], stems [e.g., sugar cane] and fruits [e.g., apples])

049AA2B1CE1743FE9105851ABD7B406D.description:
identify the major human organ systems that perform critical life functions; i.e., energy
conversion, response to the environment, growth, reproduction, and conservation or dissipation of
thermal energy

7317C5FAD6EC4BA58AF067DA37AECD1C.description: identify organs and systems in plants and animals that carry out the above life functions

5D58611E68ED4F978D00F338E896F6EF.description:
identify life functions common to living systems; i.e., energy conversion, response to the
environment, growth, reproduction, and conservation or dissipation of thermal energy (e.g.,
torpor, dormancy, hibernation, estivation, vascular skin, sweat gland behaviour)

2EB9C41738F34B46ACD03CA2F304D454.description:
describe the relationship between photosynthesis and cellular respiration in terms of biological
energy storage; i.e., capture of energy from the Sun in glucose during photosynthesis, and the
release of energy from glucose during respiration

CF4EDFA3A323407D90091E21EB37AF13.description:
Identify and compare, in general terms, the life functions common to living systems, from cells to
organ systems

A245D8F4E4664E07887EB5DC34A7E8DB.description:
describe, using analogies where appropriate, the functions of the major parts of plant and animal
cells, including the cell membrane, nucleus, vacuole, mitochondrion, chloroplast and cell wall
(e.g., compare cell functions to the functioning of a city)

44218B830FEB4E1089CCA145D53BE377.description:
describe the structure of the major parts of plant and animal cells, including the cell membrane,
nucleus, vacuole, mitochondrion, chloroplast and cell wall

9CB6AA2FB90446E78F6CD010D3054696.description:
relate human knowledge of cells to the development of the optical microscope and staining
techniques (e.g., the work of Antony van Leeuwenhoek, Robert Hooke)

9A44C99D013B4F8DB7276118EE6A0E44.description:
Describe, in general terms, the structure and function of plant and animal cell parts; and trace the
development of the cell theory

3A5A2796759943A8B0DBDB5B8F887A4B.description:
evaluate the effect of social factors on human digestive and circulatory well-being and disorders
(e.g., ulcers, anorexia, bulimia, high blood pressure, heart and arterial diseases as they relate to
lack of fitness, unbalanced diets)

9DF26F74B414402C8E530F05C7408EB6.description:
analyze and explain, in general terms, a technology that is used to diagnose imbalances (e.g.,
endoscope, stethoscope) or to intervene and preserve balance (homeostasis) (e.g., kidney dialysis
machine, pacemaker)

E9A364F1AD00412BA805FF19C36322C4.description:
explain that illness and possibly death may result when the body cannot accommodate major
disturbances within a system; i.e., digestive, excretory or circulatory (e.g., ulcers, heart attacks)

7863878D6A87437B81456A3AC944997D.description:
explain how normal fluctuations within the digestive system result in adjusting fluctuations in the
circulatory system (e.g., ingestion of salt and increased blood pressure; the relationship between
blood sugar and insulin production)

B200FE5ADA3541CA951C94CF41E0EE83.description:
describe, in general terms, how the digestive and circulatory systems interact to assist in the
maintenance of balance (homeostasis) in the human organism

C8E96B9B1409456382EEECAAF9124486.description:
Describe disorders of the digestive and circulatory systems as imbalances induced by genetic,
lifestyle and environmental factors

67230704E4694DC2A09CB0F2A54A53C5.description:
analyze the functional relationship between the digestive and circulatory systems, recognizing the
work of early physicians (e.g., William Harvey, Ivan Pavlov, William Beaumont)

032ACEBC499E4751A8D6CB981B294F31.description:
describe, in general terms, the role of the heart and lungs in the circulatory system and in the
exchange and distribution of matter processed by the digestive system

3FAA3F35F4764900A55F177514F5874B.description: analyze and discuss mixed diets and vegetarian diets in meeting human nutritional needs

EC68A87878CE4CAD83BA7380735ABF74.description:
explain, in general terms, how diets that include excessive amounts of certain foods may
influence body function (e.g., cholesterol, salt, fats)

E4F44CBBAFF641928F1CB2B40B11F22A.description:
assess the nutrient components of prepared foods by reading labels, and evaluate a variety of
popular diets in terms of nutrient composition

3AA3D88D251B45599F2349BCCF42D07F.description:
Describe, in general terms, the exchange of matter by the digestive and circulatory systems, the
functional relationship between the two systems and the need for a healthy diet and lifestyle

298B3BB8A76D424798D0F0B348934791.description: Investigating Matter and Energy in Living Systems

4291F214506F4D84AFA5886F997E795E.description:
explain the need to encourage and support the development of machines that are efficient and rely
upon renewable energy sources (e.g., hand-wound radios, solar-powered calculators, solar
cookers)

3FE8A05AFB5E484480ABF09E5603EB47.description:
explain the functioning of common household machines, in terms of force multipliers and ways in
which work is made easier (e.g., can openers, crowbars, car jacks, scissors and hedge clippers)

E03521B653154CFF93A33273B8DD5C1C.description:
develop the relationship Fd, by measuring the force (F) applied to the object and the distance (d)
the object is moved in the direction in which the force is applied (e.g., use a balance beam
[teeter-totter] to establish equilibrium, placing differing masses at various distances)

0F94B2FBCBFA461F96AAAC9B2AD33524.description:
describe all simple machines as having an input force, an output force and a fulcrum (e.g.,
pulleys, doorknobs, winches)

43DB4FFB98764F05BAA351DE5850A067.description: analyze and describe simple machines as either force multipliers or distance multipliers

6A3E3942F27C4F439A8FEC427BB2D5E0.description:
identify the joule and the newton metre as the units of energy and work in the Système
international (SI) units

2FB0C7FAD6624936A70E56C75863B7A8.description:
analyze and describe simple machines as devices that transfer energy (e.g., screws, ramps,
hammers, hockey sticks, tennis rackets)

71E820CECA9C48F8A328847E9C3F86CC.description:
Describe and compare simple machines as devices that transfer energy and multiply forces or
distances

7DF0B3BC64A842ED81556EC5CDDAF880.description:
describe the variation in absorption/loss of heat (specific heat capacity) of a substance being
heated or cooled, by manipulating variables that include the amount and type of material
(e.g., motor oil, cooking oil, water)

969AEAD5B7D9456AA9A4D3FDE72B30BA.description:
describe the functioning of devices and methods that protect against potentially dangerous
thermal energy transfer (e.g., household appliances, protective clothing worn by firefighters,
internal combustion engine)

80A25694D0734BC2898DC140200F3402.description:
explain the functioning of technologies that reduce thermal energy transfer (e.g., clothing,
construction strategies for reducing heat loss—insulation, cavity walls, aluminum foil and double
glazing)

51985D6072C840498DFBB5D4EF35378C.description:
Explain the functioning of common methods and devices designed to control the transfer of thermal
energy

1700FDAB54D04E11B1D5B163FC042534.description:
explain how large bodies of water, such as oceans and lakes, have a moderating influence on
climate (e.g., compare the climates of Vancouver and Calgary)

07E7F99D1E9A4486BAA247156A17BDEA.description:
describe the role of convection and conduction in distributing heat in natural and technological
systems (e.g., sea and land breezes, convection ovens, metal pipes, cast-iron pots and pans)

BD1FAD55A2AA4980A5DBE1008275A770.description:
describe the particle model of matter in which every object consists of particles in motion, and
describe the effect of temperature on this motion (e.g., observe Brownian motion)

E8870CEFF7F647FFAED9B0A1C69798FA.description:
describe the three ways; i.e., radiation, conduction and convection, that thermal energy is
transferred from hot to cold objects

DF8F03BCD0794C3B9A59F042EE6026D5.description:
observe and explain the functioning of cooling systems as applications that are based on the
principle that heat is transferred from hot to cold objects (e.g., fins on engines, piping on the back
of refrigerators and air conditioners, automobile radiators)

E3B89942651A43DFAFF65260233A4184.description:
Describe how natural and technological cooling and heating systems are based upon the transfer of
thermal energy (heat) from hot to cold objects

52B90A4B0B0F487890BFC8430F6B5F4A.description:
demonstrate the difference between elements and compounds on the basis of a decomposition
reaction (e.g., electrolysis of water)

C8D419AB0E504B4F9731F81A7AE7F900.description:
name and write chemical formulas for common elements (e.g., aluminum, copper, iron, nitrogen,
hydrogen, oxygen) and simple compounds (e.g., water, glucose, table salt, carbon dioxide, iron
oxide, vinegar, methane, propane), and describe the uses of elements and compounds in society

5929EF726F6348CCA924879647B1888A.description: use the periodic table to locate names and properties of elements

19B0432FC6FA48A99763B48AD156A1BA.description:
differentiate among metals, nonmetals and metalloids on the basis of properties (e.g., luster,
conductivity, malleability, brittleness, state of matter)

7D697D1C8FF5488D9DBF510D1D9C7201.description:
Describe the properties of elements and compounds, and use the periodic table to identify trends in
properties

476A46E96A3B47B3B27CAE1BFE65EB37.description:
list the potential dangers of mixing common household and industrial chemicals (e.g., mixing
ammonia cleaners with bleach, adding muriatic [hydrochloric] acid to caustic soda, adding
water to acid)

F6B11CA8D63944119ACAB14304E5BAB4.description:
describe and investigate the corrosive effects of the following environmental factors: acids,
bases, salts, humidity and temperature (e.g., corrosion of iron by acid rain and spray from ocean
water)

A7F09BD0762946118F7A2F3448ED0E80.description:
describe, in general terms, the pH scale as an indicator of acidity or basicity; i.e., a pH of less than
7 indicates an acid, a pH of 7 indicates a neutral solution, and a pH of greater than 7 indicates a
base

C2EBECE7358C48E99BDE9BBAB08605B5.description:
identify acid and base solutions in the home, job site and laboratory (e.g., vinegar, soda pop,
shampoo, battery acid, household ammonia, antacids, dish soap, hydrochloric acid, sodium
hydroxide) on the basis of their general properties; i.e., they conduct electricity, change colour of
acid/base indicators and neutralize one another

8E1870FD187B43F3992658783502E6C1.description:
compare the volume of waste packaging produced from consumer use of the concentrated and
diluted forms of products (e.g., orange juice, fabric softener), and relate this to the need for
recycling and environmental preservation

4342183F8A604EB89939EA5F1FBB0A2F.description:
link concentration changes and the concept of dilution to changes in the ratio of the amount of
solute to the amount of solvent (e.g., investigate how concentrated products, such as orange
juice, evaporated milk or instant coffee are made)

650EF41A612948788F14863BD9F4BAB7.description:
provide examples of the effect of temperature change on solubility, and explain this effect on the
basis of the particle model of matter (e.g., concentration of brines for pickling and syrups for
canning)

C093976243D242B0A6419CE98155EAED.description:
define, operationally, solute, solvent, solution and solubility; and express concentration in terms
of mass per volume

FD919EB39AC14BF3ACBB29DE76459D81.description:
provide examples of insoluble and soluble mixtures (e.g., oil and water, vinegar and water); and,
in general terms, account for the difference

F72F4D40450A4B8CA3B8F095DF7E0BD6.description:
Describe solutions and solubility, solutes and solvents; and then describe how these concepts are
applied to the production of prepared foods and other useful materials

939C4226E921439AB3A2BFD260D47B78.description: apply the particle model of matter to explain the physical properties of the phases of matter

12F706B7104F4D87812C8BC9C5E5D9F6.description: differentiate between physical and chemical properties of matter

33E7D4A12437487BA9CC65D85D946F50.description:
outline the steps in separating the components of mechanical mixtures and solutions on the basis
of their properties (e.g., filtration of mechanical mixtures, distillation of solutions such as crude
oil)

8FDAD6D198E84237A284E48F3D66A823.description:
compare and contrast the properties of pure substances and mixtures (e.g., brass and zinc,
stainless steel and iron, acetic acid and vinegar, pure water and salt water), and relate this
information to practical applications (e.g., salting icy roads, adding antifreeze to car radiators)

008F7126EEC14B1F9DE9AB464527FEC9.description:
describe the importance of mixtures and solutions in household products (e.g., baking soda,
soaps, paints)

DB5DFF4D18284F19BE6B2D1DA80BB90A.description:
describe the need for safety precautions that should be followed when handling, storing and
disposing of substances at home and in the laboratory; and explain the WHMIS and consumer
product symbols for labelling substances (e.g., flammable, corrosive, reactive, health hazard)

AC0923013CE54C8F983BE84B637FDE85.description:
Classify various forms of matter, including commonly used household substances, on the basis of
their properties, and relate these properties to their safe use, storage and disposal
